In 'Higher Topos Theory in Physics', Urs points out that linearity means abelian group structure and in higher gauge theory.

Ignoring all the physics for the moment, and sticking to linear algebra, how exactly does linear structure come about by delooping, and what is the exact relation between abelian/symmetric structure and linearity?

I mean, I doubt many people think of linear algebra as being about abelian structure, at least not it the immediate. Can someone make this a bit more explicit as to what is going on?

There's an important classical theorem that infinite loop spaces are the same as E∞E_\inftyE∞​-spaces, which are spaces with a multiplication operation that's infinitely coherently homotopy-associative and -commutative. Does that answer the first question?

I don't really know a precise notion of "linearity" that's relevant to compare to "abelian/symmetric" structure, other than that words like "linear" are often used as rough synonyms for stability, which is the property of ∞\infty∞-categories in which delooping is an auto-equivalence, which in particular gives every object an internal E∞E_\inftyE∞​-structure.

Most ordinary folks think about linear algebra as being about vector spaces, but many important features of linear algebra generalize to modules of an arbitrary commutative ring RRR, and when we take R=ZR = \mathbb{Z}R=Z these are none other than abelian groups. That's the simplest reason why "abelian" and "linear algebra" sound very similar to Urs (and me).

I've tried to indicate how we can do a generalized version of 'linear algebra' with abelian groups replacing vector spaces. Mathematicians do this all the time; they just don't tend to call it linear algebra.

Then, we can ∞\infty∞-categorify! The simplest way is to replace abelian groups by N\mathbb{N}N-graded chain complexes of abelian groups, since these are the same as

  • strict ∞\infty∞-groupoids in the category of abelian groups

or

  • abelian group objects in the category of strict ∞\infty∞-groupoids

Here the abelianness is 'tacked on' to the concept of strict ∞\infty∞-groupoid. But - though this may or may not be quite worked out yet - we can look at Z\mathbb{Z}Z-groupoids, which are a generalization of ∞\infty∞-groupoids that have nnn-morphisms for all n∈Zn \in \mathbb{Z}n∈Z. A strict Z\mathbb{Z}Z-groupoid with only one morphism for each n<0n \lt 0n<0 deserves to be called a strict stable ∞\infty∞-groupoid, and these should be the same as N\mathbb{N}N-graded chain complexes of abelian groups!

So here abelianness is arising from 'stabilization': the fact that we have a single morphism for each n<0n \lt 0n<0. This happens thanks to a version of the [[Eckmann-Hilton argument]].

However, we can get more interesting examples from [[infinite loop spaces]]: these should be the same as non-strict stable ∞\infty∞-groupoids!

The 'infinite loop' stuff is the topological way of thinking about putting in only one morphism for each n<0n \lt 0n<0.

So, infinite loop spaces are like a glorified version of chain complexes of abelian groups, and thus yet another setting for glorified 'linear algebra'.

All this generalizes further to spectra. And just as abelian groups generalize to RRR-modules for a commutative ring RRR, which are a nice context for 'linear algebra', spectra generalize to modules of an E∞E_\inftyE∞​ ring spectrum RRR.

I'm pretty sure Urs would consider modules of any E∞E_\inftyE∞​ ring spectrum an example of a context for doing 'linear algebra'.
